The depth of the clothes dryer.
The height of the clothes dryer.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.

Highly energy efficient heat pump technology typically heats, dehumidifies and circulates air in the dryer drum, so no vent is required. A Heat Pump model solely uses heat pump technology to dry clothes, while a Hybrid Heat Pump model uses a combination of heat pump technology and traditional electric resistance heating technology.

These exceptional products represent the leading edge in energy efficient products this year. For more information, please visit www.energystar.gov/mostefficient

The cycle selection and settings (temperature and dryness where separately selectable) as defined in the U.S. Department of Energy test procedure, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Section 430, Subpart B, Appendix D2, Section 3.3, used for certification to ENERGY STAR.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information on certified models in their information systems.

This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. Features applicable to the clothes dryer may include drum light, wrinkle prevention option, steam cycle, sanitization cycle, filter cleaning indicator, energy monitor/indicator, time remaining display, and supplementary drying system.

Connected appliances may or may not enable open-standards connectivity in the home. Consider the following illustrative examples: "Yes" An appliance that can directly communicate using Wi-Fi and OpenADR, or wired Ethernet and SEP 2.x; "No" An appliance that uses proprietary communications to/from the cloud, and is capable of supporting open-standards communications only in the cloud.

Refrigerants are substances that cool or heat and are often used in refrigeration and HVAC equipment. Heat pump dryers require refrigerants as well. Many refrigerants are harmful atmospheric pollutants that have a high global warming potential (GWP). Lower GWP alternative refrigerant options for clothes dryers include R-290.

columns_description: An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

Indicates whether the model has thin client capability, i.e., the ability to receive, decrypt, and display encrypted  content provided by a Multichannel Video Programming Distributor (MVPD) over the Local Area Network via a server device co-located on the customer premises without the need for a client device at the TV/HTD.
The wireless band and frequency supported by the model.
The features included with the TV.
The light output per unit area when the television is in the brightest selectable preset mode, expressed in units of candelas per square meter (cd/sq. meter).

On Mode is the power mode in which the product is connected to a mains power source, and is capable of producing dynamic video. For products with Automatic Brightness Control (ABC) enabled by default, this is the power measured when the television is exposed to 100 lux of ambient light is expressed in units of candelas per square meter (cd/sq. meter)

On Mode is the power mode in which the product is connected to a mains power source, and is capable of producing dynamic video. For products with Automatic Brightness Control (ABC) enabled by default, this is the power measured when the television is exposed to 3 lux of ambient light is expressed in units of candelas per square meter (cd/sq. meter).

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of
seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification
information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will
have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information
on certified models in their information systems.

For models with Automatic Brightness Control (ABC) enabled by default, the light output per unit area  when the television is exposed to 12 lux of ambient light is expressed in units of candelas per square meter (cd/sq. meter).
The backlight technology used in the TV.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
The market for which the product is intended.
The light output per unit area when the television is in the Picture Setting that is ENERGY STAR qualified as shipped, expressed in units of candelas per square meter (cd/sq. meter).

For models with Automatic Brightness Control (ABC) enabled by default, the light output per unit area when the television is exposed to 35 lux of ambient light is expressed in units of candelas per square meter (cd/sq. meter).

For models with Automatic Brightness Control (ABC) enabled by default, the light output per unit area when the television is exposed to 100 lux of ambient light is expressed in units of candelas per square meter (cd/sq. meter).
This calculation assumes daily operation of 5 hours in On Mode and 19 hours in either Standby-Active, Low Mode (Standby Mode When Network Connected), if available, or Standby-Passive Mode.
The date that the model is available for purchase.
The physical pixel count for the vertical axis of the television (e.g., a television with a screen resolution of 1920 x 1080 (horizontal x vertical) would have a native vertical resolution of 1080).

A unique string of characters assigned by certification
bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance
characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it
is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of
characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned
by EPA.
Since this product category is no longer covered by ENERGY STAR Most Efficient, the field is no longer relevant and will contain no data.

On Mode is the power mode in which the product is connected to a mains power source, and is capable of producing dynamic video. For products with Automatic Brightness Control (ABC) enabled by default, this is the power measured when the television is exposed to 12 lux of ambient light is expressed in units of candelas per square meter (cd/sq. meter).

The maximum Standby Mode power requirement to qualify for ENERGY STAR (does not depend on Screen Area). The Power Consumption in Standby Mode (Standby-Passive or Standby-Active, Low, whichever is applicable) cannot exceed this value.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
The viewable screen area of the product, calculated by multiplying the viewable image width by the viewable image height.

On Mode is the power mode in which the product is connected to a mains power source, and is capable of producing dynamic video. For products qualifying with Automatic Brightness Control (ABC) enabled by default, the reported On Mode Power is a weighted average of On Mode Power measured at ambient light levels of 3, 12, 35, and 100 lux. For products without ABC, the On Mode power is a measurement taken at an arbitrary light level.
The most common screen types include Liquid Crystal Display (LCD) screens, that are either LED direct-lit or LED edge-lit displays, or organic light-emitting diode (OLED).
For products that were certified with Automatic Brightness Control (ABC) enabled, the names of those preset picture settings available on this TV that have ABC enabled, are listed here.
For products that were certified with Automatic Brightness Control (ABC) enabled, the names of those preset picture settings available on this TV that do not have ABC enabled, are listed here.

The power mode in which the product is connected to a mains power source, produces neither sound nor picture, and is actively downloading data. Data downloads may include channel listing information for use by an electronic programming guide, TV setup data, channel map updates, firmware updates, monitoring for emergency messaging/communications or other network communications.
Indicates which energy saving features are enabled for this product.
The self-acting mechanism that controls the brightness of a TV as a function of ambient light.
For products that have an HDR Upscaling feature, the light output per unit area (when this feature is enabled) is expressed in units of candelas per square meter (cd/sq. meter).
For products that have a High Dynamic Range (HDR) Upscaling feature, this is the measured power with that feature enabled.

A Television is a product designed to produce dynamic video. A TV contains an internal TV tuner
encased within the product housing and is capable of receiving dynamic visual content from
wired or wireless sources. 

Also included are Home Theater Displays (HTDs), which have screen size greater than 25
inches and do not contain an internal TV tuner.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.
The self-acting mechanism that controls the brightness of a TV as a function of ambient light.
Network connections, usually using Internet Protocol (IP).

For models with Automatic Brightness Control (ABC) enabled by default, the light output per unit area when the television is exposed to 3 lux of ambient light is expressed in units of candelas per square meter (cd/sq. meter).

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification. The UPC code data below is intended to aid in identification of ENERGY STAR models. UPC code data is not provided for all certified models.
The maximum On Mode power requirement for a model with the given Screen Area and Vertical Resolution to qualify for ENERGY STAR. The Power Consumption in On Mode cannot exceed this value.

Standby mode is the mode in which the TV is connected to a power source, produces neither sound nor picture, but can be switched into another mode. This field indicates the power in Standby-Active, Low Mode, for products with an active network connection. (TVs that do not have full network connectivity will not have data in this mode)

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a  product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.
The diagonal screen size in inches.
The horizontal by vertical pixel count of the TV.

For products with Automatic Brightness Control (ABC) enabled by default, this is the power measured when the television is exposed to 35 lux of ambient light is expressed in units of candelas per square meter (cd/sq. meter).

Standby Mode is the mode in which the TV is connected to a power source, produces neither sound nor picture, but can be switched into another mode. columns_description: A distinguishing identifier, usually alphanumeric, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler.

An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. This column includes alternative means to identify the model/model family (e.g., additional model names, additional model numbers, retailer SKUs, product descriptions).

Desktop: A computer whose main unit is designed to be located in a permanent location, often on a desk or on the floor. Desktop computers are not designed for portability and are designed for use with an external display, keyboard, and mouse.

Integrated Computer: A desktop computer in which the computing hardware and display are integrated into a single housing, and which is connected to ac mains power through a single cable. Integrated desktop computers come in one of two possible forms: (1) a system where the display and computer are physically combined into a single unit; or (2) a system packaged as a single system where the display is separate but is connected to the main chassis by a dc power cord and both the computer and display are powered from a single power supply.

Notebook: A computer designed specifically for portability and to be operated for extended periods of time both with and without a direct connection to an ac mains power source.

Slate/tablet: A computing device designed for portability.

Portable All-in-one Computer: A computing device designed for limited portability.

Small-scale Server: A computer that typically uses desktop components in a desktop form factor, but is designed primarily to be a storage host for other computers. Small-scale Servers are designed to perform functions such as providing network infrastructure services (e.g., archiving) and hosting data/media.

Thin Client: An independently-powered computer that relies on a connection to remote computing resources to obtain primary functionality. Main computing functions (e.g., program execution, data storage, interaction with other Internet resources) are provided by the remote computing resources.

Workstation: A high-performance, single-user computer typically used for graphics, CAD, software development, financial and scientific applications among other compute intensive tasks.

A second-order classification or sub-type within a product type that is based on product features and installed components. Product categories are used in this specification to determine qualification and test requirements. TEC (Typical Energy Consumption) is a method of testing and comparing the energy performance of computers, which focuses on the typical electricity consumed by a product while in normal operation during a representative period of time.)
The minimum processing speed of the central processing unit (CPU).
The default power-saving mode used by the computer.

The power state in which the operating system and other software have completed loading, a user profile has been created, activity is limited to those basic applications that the system starts by default, and the computer is not in Sleep Mode. Furthermore, the Computer has reached an Idle condition, but the Display is on, and Long Idle power management features have not engaged.
The energy allowance provided by the ENERGY STAR specification for the model configuration tested as meeting Category I1 requirements, based on the Computer's other capabilities.
Typical energy consumption of the model configuration tested as meeting Category I1 requirements.
The minimum processing speed of the central processing unit (CPU).

A low power mode that the computer enters automatically after a period of inactivity or by manual selection. A computer with Sleep capability can quickly "wake" in response to network connections or user interface devices with a latency of less than or equal to 5 seconds from initiation of wake event to system becoming fully usable including rendering of display.

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Water Heaters
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 4.0 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Water Heaters that are effective January 5, 2021. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at https://www.energystar.gov/products/water_heaters/residential_water_heaters_key_product_criteria
columns_name: Recovery Efficiency per EF test method (%)
First Hour Rating at 135°F outlet temp (gallons/hr)
Minimum Gallons Per Minute over 77°F rise
Gallons/year at 125°F outlet temp for Propane
Maximum Gallons per Minute over 77°F rise
Minimum Gallons Per Minute over 67°F rise
Therms/year at 135°F outlet temp for Natural Gas
Gallons/year at 135°F outlet temp for Propane
Maximum Gallons Per Minute over 67°F rise
Therms Per Year at 125°F outlet temp
Recovery Efficiency per UEF test method (%)
First Hour Rating at 125°F outlet temp (gallons/hr)
Max. Input Rate for Gas Products (Btu/hr)
columns_description: Draw pattern used per the Appendix E test method. For storage-type water heaters, draw pattern is determined by the FHR test. For gas tankless water heaters, draw pattern is determined per Max. GPM rating test. For all solar water heaters,  draw pattern is determined by collector size.

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.
Capacity of the tank, in gallons.
Refers to the total area consumed by the solar collector.
Volume is the capacity of the tank, in gallons. Storage Volume is not applicable for gas tankless, solar with gas backup, or solar with electric backup water heaters.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.

Thermal efficiency (TE) is the ratio of the heat transferred to the water flowing through the water heater to the amount of energy consumed by the water heater. This rating is used for Light Duty EPACT units rated per the EF test method.
Electric Input kW refers to the input wattage of the heat pump or supplementary electric elements.
The water heater's width, in inches.
Maximum amperage
Fuel type refers the kind of fuel the water heater uses to heat the water, either natural gas or propane.

Standard HPWH require 240 Volt service, but certain products are appropriate for installation on a 120 Volt, 15 Amp Circuit. Split-System heat pump water heaters are residential water heaters where the compressor, evaporator, and/or condenser are separated from the storage tank.
kWh/year, kilowatt hours per year, refers to the amount of electricity consumed by the water heater according to the EF test method.
Height to vent is the distance from the bottom of the water heater’s tank to its vent.
Volume is the capacity of the tank in a solar system, in gallons.
Standby Loss (SL) means the average hourly energy required to maintain the stored water temperature. This rating is used for Light Duty EPACT units rated per the EF test method.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
Recovery efficiency refers to how efficiently the heat from the burner is transferred to the water in the tank per the EF test method.

Refrigerants are substances that cool or heat and are often used in refrigeration and HVAC equipment. Heat pump water heaters require refrigerants as well. Many refrigerants are harmful atmospheric pollutants that have a high global warming potential (GWP). Lower-GWP alternative refrigerant options for heat pump water heaters include R-744 (CO₂).
Vent size 2 is the width or diameter of a second vent opening.
First Hour Rating is the amount of hot water (in gallons) a storage water heater can supply per hour (starting with a tank full of hot water) according to the EF test method.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.
Indicates if a product is capable of responding to Set Point Adjustment and/or Relative Price Signal commands.

Energy Factor (EF) is an older measure of water heater overall efficiency that is used to compare the relative efficiencies of water heaters. This rating is no longer used in the U.S, but is provided for products sold in Canada.
The amount of hot water, in gallons, a tankless water heater can supply per minute over a 77°F rise per the EF test method.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
Gallons/year refers to the amount of propane consumed by the water heater with a tested outlet temperature of 125°F per the Appendix E test method.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information on certified models in their information systems.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned by EPA.
Voltage required for a heat pump water heater.
The limit to the system’s tolerance of freezing weather conditions.
Indicates if a Connected product responds with a Basic Load Up and/or Advanced Load Up.
Electric usage per year per Appendix E test method.
Vent size is the width or diameter of the vent opening.

Solar Water Heaters are available in the following collector types: batch, flat-plate, and evacuated tube. Batch collectors heat water in dark tanks or tubes within an insulated box, storing the water until drawn. Flat-plate collectors consist of copper tubes fitted to flat absorber plates. Evacuated tubes contain a vacuum of space around the metal or glass tube.
The water heater's height, in inches.

This field is used to indicate the type of qualified product: Gas Storage Water Heater, Gas Tankless Water Heater, Heat Pump Water Heater, High Capacity Storage, Solar with Gas Backup, or Solar with Electric Backup.
The amount of hot water, in gallons, a tankless water heater can supply per minute over a 77°F rise per the EF test method.
The minimum amount of hot water, in gallons, a tankless water heater can supply per minute over a 67°F rise per the UEF test method.
The date that the model is available for purchase.
Therms/year refers to the amount of natural gas consumed by the water heater according to the EF test method.

Indicates whether the model offers advanced controls and increased functionality such as the ability to turn off the unit remotely when not at home and feedback on the energy use of the product. Water heaters with connected functionality are smart grid ready; if linked with your energy provider or an energy management system these products can dynamically adjust their energy use, potentially lowering your electric bill.
Indicates if a water heater is capable of storing and operating based on Time of Use rates
The electrical energy consumption rate for gas instantaneous water heaters, in kW.
This field is used to indicate whether the backup to the solar system is a tank or is tankless.
The type of vent used by the water heater: Atmospheric Vent, Direct Vent, or Power Vent.

UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification. The UPC code data below is intended to aid in identification of ENERGY STAR models. UPC code data is not provided for all certified models.
Tank diameter is the width or diameter of the water heater’s tank.
Gallons/year refers to the amount of propane consumed by the water heater according to the EF test method.
Sound pressure level as measured per the NEEA Electric or Gas-Fueled Advanced Water Heating Specification, in dBA

The maximum amount of hot water, in gallons, a tankless water heater can supply per minute over a 67°F rise per the Appendix E test method. This value is calculated for products that do not display UEF data.

Uniform Energy Factor (UEF) is the newest measure of water heater overall efficiency. It is a metric used to compare the relative efficiencies of water heaters. The higher the UEF is, the more efficient the water heater.
Therms/year refers to the amount of natural gas consumed by the water heater with a tested outlet temperature of 125°F per the Appendix E test method.
Recovery efficiency refers to how efficiently the heat from the burner is transferred to the water in the tank per the Appendix E test method.
The water heater's depth, in inches.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
First Hour Rating is the amount of hot water (in gallons) a storage water heater can supply per hour (starting with a tank full of hot water) per the UEF test method.
The rate at which energy is consumed by the gas water heater when running at maximum capacity, in BTU/hr.
Tank height is the distance from the bottom of the water heater’s tank to the top of its tank.

Forced Circulation systems use a pump to circulate the water or other fluid from the collector where it is heated by the sun to the storage tank. Integral Collector Storage (ICS) systems, or “batch” water heaters, combine the collector and the storage tank into one. Thermosyphon systems have a separate storage tank, located above the collector. Liquid (which could be water or an antifreeze solution) warmed in the collector rises to the storage tank.
Solar Uniform Energy Factor (SUEF) refers to the energy delivered by the total system divided by the electrical or gas energy put into the system.
Auxiliary Input refers to the input BTU per hour rating of the backup gas water heater in the solar system, in thousand BTU per hour.

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Light Fixtures
resource.description: Please note, as of January 5, Ceiling Fan Light Kits are no longer included in this dataset. The Ceiling Fan Light Kit dataset can be found here: https://data.energystar.gov/Active-Specifications/ENERGY-STAR-Certified-Ceiling-Fans-Light-Kit/3zeh-haeu/data. Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 2.0, 2.1, or 2.2 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Luminaires. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at http://www.energystar.gov/index.cfm?fuseaction=find_a_product.showProductGroup&pgw_code=LU#specs.
columns_name: Energy Efficiency - Measured Outside the Fixture (lumens/Watt)
Energy Efficiency - Measured at the Source (lumens/Watt)
columns_description: The expected useful life of the light source. Measured differently depending on the technology of the light source. For example, LED lighting expected useful life is based on the estimated point at which only 70% of the original light output remains, while for older technologies, like fluorescent and halogen, estimated useful life is based on the measured median sample life.

The R9 value is not included in the Color Rendering Index (CRI) score but important for a light source to show red in objects with red in them, such as skin tones, natural wood tones, produce, meats, and artwork. Higher numbers represent more accurate rendering of red.

Most fixtures are designed to operate on an on/off switch. However, some fixtures have been designed with features to perform in specialized applications, such as with dimmers, three-way, or photo cell controls. Special features and compatibility with controls should be clearly marked on the product packaging, cut sheet or web site for the product. For light fixtures shipped with ENERGY STAR bulbs, the special features may apply to either the bulb or fixture.
Indicates if the lamp manufacturer claims that the lamp is dimmable and meets the requirements in the specification.

The appearance of the light is indicated by the Correlated Color Temperature (CCT) on the Kelvin scale. Lower Kelvin numbers like 2700-3000K mean the light appears more “warm” like incandescent; a CCT of 3500-4100K mean the light is whiter and higher temperatures like 5000-6500K would appear slightly bluer. Light appearance is indicated on bulb packaging.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
Indicates information on certification relevant to the consumer (i.e. product variations, unique issues concerning the model’s listing, etc.).

The Color Rendering Index (CRI) of a light source represents the degree of color shift objects undergo when illuminated by the light source as compared with the color of those same objects when illuminated by a reference source of comparable color temperature. The ENERGY STAR specifications require a CRI of at least 80. Incandescent lighting has a CRI of 100. Early fluorescent lighting had CRIs in the 60s, resulting in unpleasant appearance of skin tones.
Indicates if a recessed downlight fixture is insulation contact (IC) rated or airtight.

A description of the "color" of a light source measured on the Kelvin (K) scale. CFLs are available in a range of color temperatures. Lower values (2700-3000K) mean the white light has a warmer (red-yellow) tone, while higher kelvin (4100-6500K) mean the white light has a cooler (bluer) tone.
The aperture size in inches for recessed downlight fixtures.

Measured outside the Fixture (lm/W): The quotient of the total luminous flux (lumens) emitted by the fixture over the total power input (Watts). It is expressed in lumens per watt (lm/W). For ENERGY STAR qualified fixtures this applies to light fixtures that are measured at the fixture level. This includes the following residential grade directional fixture types: line-voltage track lights, ceiling fan light kits, undercabinet and cove lighting, downlights, recessed, pendant or surface mounted and includes retrofit kits for existing recessed cans. This also includes the following LIMITED commercial fixture types: Accent lights such as line-voltage track lights, under cabinet task lights, portable desk task lights, downlights, recessed, pendant or surface-mounts BUT EXCLUDES typical commercial and industrial fixtures such as recessed troffers or linear forms (e.g. linear fluorescent pendants) typically used in office spaces.
Light sources can be fully integrated into a light kit or removable by a consumer by custom connectors, wire nuts, pronged plugs like GU10, GU24 or sockets e.g. E26 known as the Edison base.
The ENERGY STAR Manufacturing Partner is the organization that has signed an ENERGY STAR Partnership Agreement and labels the model. This organization is typically the brand owner.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.
The light source technology utilized by the fixture: compact fluorescent light (CFL), light emitting diode (LED), or halogen.

The quotient of the total light source/lamp luminous flux (lumens) emitted over the total lamp power input (Watts). It is expressed in lm/W. For ENERGY STAR qualified fixtures this applies to light fixtures that are residential only, considered "non-directional" and have been measured at the light source level.

The ratio of real power that flows to the light source versus the amount of power actually consumed.  A light fixture with a lower power factor will draw more current than a luminaire with a higher power factor for the same amount of power consumed.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of
seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification
information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will
have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information
on certified models in their information systems.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
For fixtures with removable light sources, the shape of the light source.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information on certified models in their information systems.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information on certified models in their information systems.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification
bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance
characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it
is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of
characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned
by EPA.
The date that the model is available for purchase.
Total power consumed by the luminaire while in use.

The amount of light emitted by the light source or light fixture. Non directional fixtures (with removable light sources i.e. GU24 base bulbs) are measured at the light source and do not account for light lost from the fixture, while other fixtures meant to put light on a specific application (e.g. recessed downlights, under cabinet lights, accent lights, cove lights) are measured at the fixture level, only counting the light that escapes the fixture.

UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification. The UPC code data below is intended to aid in identification of ENERGY STAR models. UPC code data is not provided for all certified models.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.

Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.

The rate of a hot food holding cabinets energy consumption while it is maintaining or holding at the control set point, without using a humidity-generating device.
Determined using straight-line segments following the gross interior dimensions of the appliance (Interior Volume = Interior Height x Interior Width x Interior Depth).
Calculated value utilizing the equations in Section 3, Table 1 of the ENERGY STAR Product Specification for Commercial Hot Food Holding Cabinets.

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Commercial Water Heaters

columns_description: Vent size is the width or diameter of the vent opening.
The average hourly energy, expressed in Btu/hr, required to maintain the stored water temperature.
Heat output refers to the useful heat transferred to the water, in thousand BTU per hour.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

A distinguishing, alphanumeric identifier, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. The model number may include a wildcard that can be replaced by any letter or digit and still accurately capture what is covered by the model’s ENERGY STAR certification; an asterisk symbol (*) represents a letter, and a number symbol (#) a digit.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of
seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification
information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will
have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information
on certified models in their information systems.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
Tank diameter is the width or diameter of the water heater’s tank.

UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification. The UPC code data below is intended to aid in identification of ENERGY STAR models. UPC code data is not provided for all certified models.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
Vent size 2 is the width or diameter of a second vent opening.

This column includes for the certified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a  product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.
This field is used to indicate the type of qualified product: Gas Storage Water Heater, Gas Storage-type Tankless Water Heater, Gas Tankless Water Heater, or Electric Heat Pump Water Heater.
The date that the model is available for purchase.
Fuel type refers to the kind of fuel that the water heater uses to heat the water, either natural gas or propane for gas-fired water heaters, or electric for heat pump water heaters.

All of these features are optional for ENERGY STAR Partners to report to EPA.
The four features include: Fault Detection and Display - the equipment reports, in plain text, system faults that have occurred; Performance Reporting - the equipment is capable of reporting at least three performance metrics such as fuel usage, hot water use, etc.; Energy Savings Reporting - the equipment is capable of analyzing performance to report potential energy savings opportunities to the user; Predictive Maintenance - the equipment is capable of tracking water heater use and wear rates to predict and alert the user of potential maintenance requirements.
The dimensionless ratio of the useful heat transfer gained by the water to the rate of electrical power consumed during full input rate operation.
The type of vent used by the water heater: Atmospheric Vent, Direct Vent, or Power Vent.
Electric Input refers to the input wattage of the heat pump and ancillary electric components (e.g., fans, blowers, storage tank, piping, and controls).
The ratio of the heat transferred to the water flowing through the water heater to the amount of energy consumed by the water heater.
Height to vent is the distance from the bottom of the water heater's tank to its vent.
Tank height is the distance from the bottom of the water heater's tank to the top of its tank.
The amount of water contained in the water heater measured in gallons. Some tankless water heaters do not have a storage volume.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification
bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance
characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it
is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of
characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned
by EPA.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR certified products.
Input refers to the burner size of the gas-fired water heater, in thousand BTU per hour.

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Electric Vehicle Supply Equipment
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 1.0 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Electric Vehicle Supply Equipment that are effective as of December 27, 2016.  A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at https://www.energystar.gov/products/evse_key_product_criteria.

columns_description: This indicates the Idle Mode Input Power for all models and for those with ABC enabled. For those with ABC enabled, this is the average Input Power for the high and low illuminance conditions.
This indicates the Idle Mode Input Power for the Level 2 option of a dual input model. For those with ABC enabled, this is the average Input Power for the high and low illuminance conditions.
The date that the model is available for purchase.

This indicates the Full Current Operation Mode Total Loss for all models and for those with ABC enabled. For those with ABC enabled, this is the average Full Current Operation Mode Loss for the high and low illuminance conditions.

This indicates the 30 A Operation Mode Total Loss for all models and for those with ABC enabled. For those with ABC enabled, this is the average Full Current Operation Mode Loss for the high and low illuminance conditions.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned by EPA.
This indicates if this model is capable of connected functionality, as defined in the specification.
This indicates the number of outputs available for this model.

UPC codes provided by partners for ENERGY STAR certified products. The brand, model name and model number continue to serve as the identifiers used to establish certification. The UPC code data below is intended to aid in identification of ENERGY STAR models. UPC code data is not provided for all certified models.

This indicates the 30 A Operation Mode Total Loss for the Level 2 option of a dual input model. For those with ABC enabled, this is the average Full Current Operation Mode Loss for the high and low illuminance conditions.
This indicates which, if any, network protocols that the model is shipped with, and None if the model does not have any network connected capability.
This indicates summarizes the connected functionality capabilities if the model has connected functionality.
The screen area, if the EVSE has a high resolution display.

This indicates the Idle Mode Power Factor for the Level 2 option of a dual input model. For those with ABC enabled, this is the average Idle Mode Power Factor for the high and low illuminance conditions.

This indicates the No Vehicle Mode Power Factor for the Level 2 option of a dual input model. For those with ABC enabled, this is the average No Vehicle Mode Power Factor for the high and low illuminance conditions.

This indicates the 15 A Operation Mode Total Loss for all models and for those with ABC enabled. For those with ABC enabled, this is the average Full Current Operation Mode Loss for the high and low illuminance conditions.
The Idle Mode Requirement is the maximum amount of power allowed in this mode for the model to be ENERGY STAR certified.
This indicates the No Vehicle Mode Input Power for all models and for those with ABC enabled. For those with ABC enabled, this is the average Input Power for the high and low illuminance conditions.

This indicates the 15 A Operation Mode Total Loss for the Level 2 option of a dual input model. For those with ABC enabled, this is the average Full Current Operation Mode Loss for the high and low illuminance conditions.

This indicates the Idle Mode Power Factor for all models and for those with ABC enabled. For those with ABC enabled, this is the average Idle Mode Power Factor for the high and low illuminance conditions.

Indicates if the model has the transceiver and/or necessary hardware to support smart charging (i.e. beyond simple managed charging with pulse width modulation or CANBus) using any of these station-to-vehicle protocols.
This indicates the input voltage.
This indicates cord set length or mean cord set length, if multiple-output. If 0, there is no cord provided with the model during testing.
The Idle Mode Requirement is the maximum amount of power allowed in this mode for the model to be ENERGY STAR certified for the Level 2 option of a dual input model.
The No Vehicle Mode Requirement is the maximum amount of power allowed in this mode for the model to be ENERGY STAR certified for the Level 2 option of a dual input model.

This indicates the 4 A Operation Mode Total Loss for all models and for those with ABC enabled. For those with ABC enabled, this is the average Full Current Operation Mode Loss for the high and low illuminance conditions.

This indicates the 4 A Operation Mode Total Loss for the Level 2 option of a dual input model. For those with ABC enabled, this is the average Full Current Operation Mode Loss for the high and low illuminance conditions.

This indicates the Partial On Mode Power Factor for the Level 2 option of a dual input model. For those with ABC enabled, this is the average Partial On Mode Power Factor for the high and low illuminance conditions.
This indicates which type of EVSE describes this model.
This information is not applicable.
The Partial On Mode Requirement is the maximum amount of power allowed in this mode for the model to be ENERGY STAR certified for the Level 2 option of a dual input model.
This information is not applicable.
This information is not applicable.
This information is not applicable.
This indicates other features of this EVSE (e.g., vehicle to grid capability, Smart Home Energy Management System (SHEMS) compatibility, etc.).
Maximum luminance of the display, if EVSE has a high resolution display measured at maximum available brightness.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
This information is not applicable.

If the model meets the optional connected functionality criteria, this indicates which communication standard(s) are used in the application layer (e.g., Smart Energy Profile, OpenADR, Open Charge Point Protocol, etc.)
This information is not applicable.
This indicates the maximum nameplate current in Amperes.

This indicates the Full Current Operation Mode Total Loss for the Level 2 option of a dual input model. For those with ABC enabled, this is the average Full Current Operation Mode Loss for the high and low illuminance conditions.
This indicates the Partial On Mode Input Power for the Level 2 option of a dual input model. For those with ABC enabled, this is the average Input Power for the high and low illuminance conditions.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
This information is not applicable.
This indicates if this model is capable of the self-acting mechanism that controls the brightness of a display or lamp as a function of ambient light.
This indicates the No Vehicle Mode Input Power for the Level 2 option of a dual input model. For those with ABC enabled, this is the average Input Power for the high and low illuminance conditions.
The cord set American Wire Gauge (AWG) used for test or mean cord set AWG if multiple-output. If no cord was provided for testing, then there will be a NA.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information on certified models in their information systems.

This indicates the Partial On Mode Input Power for all models and for those with ABC enabled. For those with ABC enabled, this is the average Input Power for the high and low illuminance conditions.
